Niall Cullen Down -Meath -NFL DIVISION A.prettyPhoto

title: Dozens walk in memory of Seaforde Special Olympian
story: UPWARDS of  people took part in a charity walk around Castlewellan Lake on Saturday in memory of Seaforde man Glenn McBride, who died  weeks ago.Glennwas a medalled Special Olympics competitor who enjoyed soccer and basketball, playing both to a high standard.He was a popular member of of Down Special Olympics Club in Downpatrick and Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club in Newcastle.Glenn won a soccer gold medal with Team Down at the Area Games in Belfast in  and was a member of the Ulster soccer team at the Ireland Games the following year. He won a basketball gold medal with Team Ulster at the Ireland Games in .His friend Harry Walsh organised the walk in aid of the Belfast Cancer Centre to honour Glennrsquos commitment to the people who looked after him so well when he was ill.While Glenn had originally wanted to host a charity football match, he suggested a sponsored walk instead as it would be more Covid-aware.He never got the chance to host the walk but Harry continued it with it in his memory.Harry described his friend as having ldquothe kindest heart and soul who was always considerate to others.ldquoHe was never judgemental, and his passing has shown what a fantastic inspirational friend he was to many, he wrote on Facebook.ldquoHis passing is a huge loss and has left a massive hole in the lives of his family, his friends, me personally and this world in general..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 30%2C 2011
story: DOWNPATRICK mdash Down District could be in line for a multi-million pound investment package which has the potential to create several hundred new jobs.Private talks between a number of key players in the financial and construction industries have been taking place over the past number of months and a major announcement is expected shortly.The core of the talks focused on Downpatrickrsquos poundm business park and an investment package of several million pounds has been put together to unlock its huge potential.It has emerged that plans are at an advanced stage to build a number of purpose built units at a -acre site at the Belfast Road complex to entice major companies to set up businesses in the area.The plan is to have business units in place to ensure that when investors do express an interest in coming to the area, they can move in almost immediately.One of the key men involved in the talks is local councillor Harvey Bicker and he has no doubt the amount of finance which has been put together can pave the way for ldquountold opportunities in the area.He has been able to secure the support of major financial players who have already agreed with the IDB to build the so-called advance factories at the Downpatrick business park.It is understood one major company is already interested in relocating its business to the Belfast Road site and several others are also believed to have expressed an interest in the -acre complex.NEWCASTLE mdash A teacher at Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has this week discovered she is in a class of her own.A favourite amongst pupils, work colleagues and parents, Karen Caulfield, head of maths at the college, has been shortlisted for the prestigious Teacher of the Year award.The Rostrevor woman had been secretly nominated by several teaching colleagues and by parents of her students.According to school principal Kevin Lambe, Mrs Caulfieldrsquos colleagues entered her for the award as they were so impressed by her leadership qualities, her ability to inspire students, her innovative work and her organisation of the schoolrsquos numeracy strategy.ldquoMrs Caulfield is a wonderful teacher and a real asset to our college. Her colleagues all say that she has a real gt for helping students have confidence in their own ability, he said.KILLYLEAGH mdash The charred remains of Killyleagh GAA club, gutted in a blaze in the early hours of Monday morning, are to be demolished.The fire completely engulfed the clubhouse at Wolfe Tone Park, and it has been decided by club and Down County Board officials to demolish the clubhouse instead of refurbishing it.The building has been lying vacant since last year after the Wolfe Tone Club encountered financial dficulties and its teams were withdrawn from the Down leagues.The blaze, which spelled the final fate of the building, took place in the early hours of Monday morning.Downpatrick fire crews were alerted shortly after am and on arrival at the scene had to call for assistance from Ballynahinch and Comber to help control the flames.It took firemen more than four hours to bring the fire under control and by am on Monday morning all that was left of the vacant building was a crumbling shell and an acrid smell of hot ash.BALLYNAHINCH mdash A Ballynahinch student is flying high after gaining his private pilotrsquos licence.After months of gruelling training Phillip Miskimminrsquos dream of piloting a plane for a prestigious airline and travelling the world is well within his reach.As most  year-olds hop into the seat of a car, Phillip is now able to jump into the cockpit of a light aircraft, but the ambitious high-flyer is not going to settle at that.He is determined to one day become a flight captain for a commercial airline, flying passengers to destinations across the globe.Phillip was trained for his private pilotrsquos licence at Aldergrove Airport and was funded by a scholarship which he won from the Guild of Air Pilots and Navigators.The successful teenager was also the winner of the John Landymore trophy which is awarded to the most outstanding scholarship winner.Currently an aeronautical engineering student at Queenrsquos University, the former pupil of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick has the world at his feet.The young pilot has had a passion for flying since he was  and is thrilled that he can now actually fly an aircraft.KILLOUGH mdash Raised from the ashes by the local community, Killough Hall once again stands proudly in the heart of the village.Local people, young and old, flocked to the newly built youth and community centre at Palatine Square to celebrate itrsquos official opening on Friday, four years after an overnight fire left it completely gutted.In an admirable community drive local people have resurrected the building which had been part of the local village for generations.Well known author historian and Killough native, Dr Maurice Hayes, officially unveiled the new centre which will provide leisure facilities, further education courses and a social venue for all.Reminiscing about his childhood days when he used to go to the hall every Saturday afternoon for his ldquohated dance classes, a jovial Dr Hayes said it was wonderful that the hall has been restored.Mr Hayes said everyone who worked so hard to get the hall back on its feet have helped bring a new heart and le into the building and a new heart and le into Killough.STRANGFORD ndash Bank Holiday Monday was a busy day for local RNLI and Coastguard members, with two call-outs off the County Down coastline.The first incident took place at around .pm in Strangford Lough when a sailing dinghy, with three men onboard, capsized close to The Long Sheelagh rock.One of the men was rescued by a passing fishing vessel while the others were clinging to the boatrsquos hull when Portaferry leboat arrived. A Wessex helicopter from RAF Aldergrove joined the rescue and members of Portaferry Coastguard were called to assist.ldquoAll three casualties were winched to the helicopter and taken to shore close to Kircubbin Sailing Club. None of the men, who were wearing wet suits and le jackets, were seriously injured and it is believed adverse weather conditions caused the boat to overturn, said a Coastguard spokeswoman.As this incident was closing and the helicopter had just landed the casualties, Coastguards then received information that two young boys were being blown offshore in a small boat close to Ballyhornan.ldquoThe helicopter was re-tasked and itrsquos crew stood by with members of the Ardglass Coastguard unit, but the children, who were aged  and , were able to make it back to shore safely, she added.SAINTFIELD ndash Teenagers in Saintfield are being blamed for vandalising stone walls and blocking a river in the town.Concerned residents in Shrewsbury Dale have voiced their concern about what is happening and asked local councillor Robert Burgess to address the problem.Mr Burgess said residents and local farmers are becoming increasingly concerned at the behaviour of the teenagers and highlighted the importance of making them realise the error of their ways.He explained that over the past number of months, children have punched holes in local hedgerows to gain access to fields adjacent to the Shrews-bury Dale housing development.ldquoLivestock and horses have been in the fields concerned and we have to be thankful they did not escape as a result of the childrenrsquos action, Mr Burgess continued..prettyPhoto

title: New £50k play park at Downpatrick school
story: A DOWNPATRICK primary school has officially opened its new pound, playground and garden facilities.St Colmcillersquos Primary School in Glebetown Drive now has a new sensory garden called the Rainbow garden, an outdoor play park and a new welcome garden at the schoolrsquos front door.School principal Stephen Austin said the facilities were financed by pound, raised by the careful management of the school budget and pound, from the schoolrsquos Parents, Teachers and Friends Association .Planns were drawn up last June and the work by contractor, All Play Ballynahinch, began in January.Mr Austin explained: ldquoThe school is set on a spacious site with several large green areas.ldquoI wanted to maximise the learning potential of our school site to improve pupils holistic learning experiences, particularly within the areas of outdoor education, activity based and play based learning which are essential areas of the curriculum and so important in eliciting enthusiasm in learning and developing key skills in core areas such as literacy, numeracy, ICT and STEAM.ldquoI also wanted to enhance facilities for our wonderful children who deserve the best and who were disadvantaged by interruptions to their schooling in recent times due to the Covid pandemic. But also to strengthen school community and pride in our fantastic school.Mr Austin paid tribute to the schools PTFA for its fundraising, to the board of governors for support and a group of volunteers who worked on the welcome garden.ldquoThe team spirit that has been displayed throughout this project has been uplting and a reflection of the strong school community that exists within St Colmcilles Primary School, he said.ldquoThe board of governors have supported this project throughout and are committed to a cycle of continuous improvement of all aspects of the school, especially its facilities and resourcesHe continued: ldquoThe PTFA have fundraised relentlessly through organising ious raffles, draws, bingos and hampers. They have enjoyed amazing support from our parents and the whole school community who all have been very generous. So far, they have contributed pound, to the project which has allowed us to go the extra mile with more extensive resources and a very high spec finish in the ious areas.He said that the welcome garden was created almost exclusively by volunteers such as grandparent Stephen Vaughan, who built the planter boxes, the garden furniture was designed and constructed by brothers Lawrence and Gareth Blaney, the circular stone planter built by parent Fergus Rooney , grounds work was carried out by Pascal Magee and planting by Bill Carew. Plants and shrubs were provided at a discounted rate from Cunningham Flowers in Dundrum.The schoolrsquos head of outdoor education, Sean McReynolds, oversaw the project with building supervisors Brian Tweedie and Bill Carew, classroom assistant Ryan Craig and Gemma Vaughan, the schoolrsquos eco co-ordinator.Parent Roisin McKenna, who along with Andrea McMenamin, Natasha Shields and Rosaleen Cunlfe leads the PTFA committee, said that they had enjoyed ldquoamazing support from parents, the wider school community and local businesses.Roisin said: ldquoThe ethos of our PTFA is about "making memories" and this is always at the forefront of our fundraising. We wanted the money we raised to benefit every child in the school and therefore the school have all the children timetabled for outdoor learning everyday.ldquoThis makes our fundraising all worthwhile when you see happy children playing daily outdoors.The PTFA organised fundraising initiatives like bingo, raffles, hampers and draws which have allowed the school to further develop the footprint of the planned facilities for the children.The schoolrsquos Rainbow garden includes a tepee, a water wall for directing and controlling the flow of water, an activity table, a water and sand tray, outdoor shelter, sensory plants with a vivid colour or smell and plastic coated activity table where children can paint use sand and textiles to show their learning.Therersquos also an outdoor classroom which can hold up to  pupils and adults with bespoke seating and a blackboard with outdoor musical equipment.Itrsquos contained within ranch style fencing and is very popular with all the schoolrsquos pupils, particularly those within its learning support centres, many of whom have complex sensory needs.The new play park contains swings, slide, climbing tower, monkey bars, balance equipment, ropes, seesaws seating and planting areas.Children are timetabled at break and lunch times and for certain lessons throughout the day.An eye-catching circular stone planter has been filled with a iety of shrubs and trees in the new Welcome garden.Therersquos also a bespoke reading area overlooking four large rectangular sleeper planter boxes filled with beautul summer flowers, a solar powered water fountain, a bird bath and bird tables..prettyPhoto

title: Politicians gather to mark Northern Ireland centenary
story: CROSSGAR marked Northern Irelandrsquos centenary on Monday with a special event.A number of local politicians including South Down MLA Harry Harvey and Rowallane councillors Billy Walker, Terry Andrews, Robert Burgess and Kathryn Owen met in the village square with each holding a torch which symbolised what happened in Crossgar a century ago when the province was formed.On that occasion, a bonfire was lit in the square by local residents to celebrate the creation of Northern Ireland on election night of the new parliament.The local MP was Sir James Craig, the first Prime Minister of Northern Ireland who had personal ties to Crossgar and had been its Westminster MP since .To mark the national and local event, local politicians from all parties were invited to hold a flame in a triangular shape on Monday symbolising the fire that was lit on the birth of the country in .Cllr Walker said he was delighted to have been invited to Crossgar to take part in the special event to mark Northern Irelandrsquos th birthday..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to Down Rec soccer legend Jim Connolly
story: JIM Connolly died on April  after a hard fought two year battle with illness.His passing was marked by a phenomenal level of tributes.Social media,work colleagues, team-mates and opponents alike expressed how well liked and respected he was in all walks of le.He was first and last a family man whether it was his brothers and sisters, Angie and his children or his beloved grandchildren.However Coot, as he was known, had another family which he held dear. He had been a vital cog in the Down Rec team which enjoyed great success in the late Seventies.But it was and remains the case that the Down Rec experience is defined by the enduring friendships which have stood the test of time.Coot grew up in Stream Street and the reason he knocked back opportunities to perform at levels his talent merited may well lie there.That part of Downpatrick had three working class housing developments, Ardpatrick and Russell Park with Stream Street and Ibrox Park in the middle.Ibrox was their playground, the place where Coot first kicked a football.He was a Stream Street kid and it seems he never wanted to be anything .When Jim Prior took him to Down Rec, it was a marriage made in heaven.In that dressing room you had another more senior Stream Street kid. Coot would have idolized Tony lsquoDartrsquo Curran in those days as he was the leader of the pack.Russell Park resident Barney Fitzsimmons was there too, a swashbuckling goalscorer who enjoyed something akin to Roy of the Rovers status at the time.Then you had the late great Paddy lsquoGeordyrsquo Galbraith, who combined a hard man reputation with a heart of gold.Peter Mulhall was another player he would have admired, a winner who proved the perfect centre back partner for the laid-back Coot.The total respect he had for them was accorded to all of us even though he was a better player than any of us. That was Coot Connolly.Prior realized that he needed to recruit from outside Downpatrick to fulfill his ambitions for the club and over a period of time he recruited players from Portaferry, Strangford, Ardglass, Dundrum, Crossgar, Saintfield, Killyleagh and Ballygowan.They were brought in for their ability but Jim couldnrsquot have known that the erse personalities therein would create the perfect storm in the dressing room.Neither could he have anticipated the level of support which flowed from those villages in the seasons to come.Dressing rooms are bastions of banter and slagging and with Dart jester-in chief, the group relished every minute they spent together.The five strong Portaferry contingent proved to be a vital ingredient, their earthy Ards humour and the opportunities their accents provided for slagging sealing their popularity.Jackie Leckey and Barney Ross brought another dimension willing as they were to join in the shenanigans on and off the pitch. Coot loved the craic and happily joined in the banter.However, he left the slagging to other less sensitive creatures of which there were plenty.A good example was the time I decided to get the footballers perm which was in vogue at the time. I should have known better.I got slaughtered, Dart declaring that I looked more like Shirley Temple than Kevin Keegan.Those were the days, as the saying goes, but happily there were plenty of good days ahead of us.We have had many reunions with Coot, an ever present and every one of them underlined the strength of the bond we enjoy so much.Sadly those reunions tend to be confined to wakes and funerals nowadays and the baby of our team has now joined Shane Breen, Paddy Galbraith and Marty Ross on the sidelines.Coot would have been the first to remind me that the Rec wasnrsquot only about the players.The one and only Charlie Oakes was highly influential in his role as assistant manager, while Austy Keating doubled as chairman and groundsman for many years.Joe Lyttle was our physio and his son Joea loyal player for years while my sister Tina was a committee member and a fanatical fan.They were all fully paid up members of the Rec family and we continue to mourn their loss.I would love to have name checked every single member of the Rec family in this piece but time and space didnrsquot allow. My apologies.The laughter which rang through Cootrsquos house during his wake was a fitting farewell for someone who loved to laugh.He was a very special human being. We will miss him forever. Rest in peace mate..prettyPhoto

story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. story: Ex-DUP MLA: Arlene Foster has undermined the Union and NI is in a dangerous place – but a united Ireland could work   Dr Christian Jessen seeks public help to fight Arlene Foster libel Lowry: There is much confusion in unionism, so here are some suggested core pro Union principlesConfirmation of Edwin Poots and Doug Beattie as leaders of their parties ought to be the start of a new political era.By Ben LowrySaturday, th May , : pmUpdated Saturday, th May , : pm  "       "   BBC" "" width"" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMxMTEMDYx.jpg crop:,smartwidth w, crop:,smartwidth w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMxMTEMDYx.jpg crop:,smartwidth w"Westminster. Ben Lowry writes: "We should emphasise our integral place in one of the great parliamentary democracies, in a country that is a world leader in science and arts, and our shared history and institutions such as theBBC"A moderate Ulster Unionist Party and a conservative DUP.Instead, there was drama in the DUP, which reflected unionist confusion. But unionism can be open minded on many issues while standing firm on these principles:. Challenge the idea of a ‘process’ That republican concept of a peace ‘process’ is used to move Northern Ireland halfway between the UK and Republic of Ireland, via small concessions . But the UK hasagreed that Scotland and Northern Ireland can leave on a % +  vote. Spain, Canada, France, the US, do not make it so easy for their regions to go. UK nationalists have won an advantage that is the dream of separatists where. In , there must be no dilution of sovereignty unless and until there is a vote to go.. Three strands must be observedLast year the DUP let Dublin jointly author a deal toStormont that included policy pledges that were Strand One matters . Doug Beattie wanted the UUP to go into opposition then. If the assembly falls again, there need to be clear demarcation as to which political talks involve Irish officials, particularly given that Ireland pushes nationalist concerns while the UK stays neutral.. SF won’t get reward for collapseSinn Fein brought down Stormont over RHI yet its only unwavering red line for ato devolution was an Irish language act . Unionists let their reasonable opposition to blackmail be depicted as ‘both sides’ having red lines. They should never again endorse a deal that rewards blackmail. . Beware of culture warsShowing proper respect for Gaelic culture such as language and sport is essential, but should not tip into weakness in the face of openly stated republican aims to use culture to secure political advance. . Seek friends across IrelandThe republican electoral march on both sides of the border is not inevitable as shown by the  general election, and the slow SF Dail advance in the decade after .Nationalist Ireland was ambivalent about the IRA in the Troubles, reflected in Irish extradition policy, but support for the Provisionals was small. Among NI Catholics, , %+ consistently voted against Sinn Fein after they began contesting elections in the s. The Republic was even more anti. The SF got %-% until the late s.Unionists have rarely courted SF critics, even those who became Taoiseach . Such leaders need support, given that elements of Fianna Fail and Fine Gael seem happy to usher SF into power. . Develop diplomatic skillsNorthern Ireland unionists seem to have few friends, yet the pool of potential allies is vast in England and Wales, given shared history. Scotland, even more so.Much of the American establishment still sees itself as Scots Irish . And many more are fond of the British link, despite the historic breach, and could be sympathetic to points such as NI’srole in the still close UK-US alliance.I have also seen curious visitors, who have no prior NI link, arrive branding unionists oppressors but leave seeing them as a vulnerable minority.. Don’t let NI be a ‘place apart’A nationalist strategy, in Scotland and NI, is to make it so dferent from England and Wales as to be unrecognisable as part of the UK.NI unionists are acquiescing in this, in part due to confusion about what is local and what is national. Core issues such as defence and trade are decided at national level of any state, something the NI protocol shatters .The Tory Henry Hill wants a new Campaign for Equal Citizenship for Northern Ireland within the UK.. Challenge misuse of ‘rights’Gerry Adams said “what’s going to break them is equality”. Influential people of a similar mindset seem to think the citing of ‘human rights’ in court to change policy will do the same. The  Stormont deal advanced a Bill of Rights for NI, which republicans hope will separate us from GB and strike down laws. No unionist should back it. Don’t be mercenary about moneyMoney is the benefit unionists most cite about the UK but a grasping approach alienates people in GB. We should emphasise our integral place in one of the great parliamentary democracies, in a country that is a world leader in science and arts, and our shared history and institutions such as theBBC.. Pay heed to history and legacyThe IRA have made legacy a priority and are turning the narrative against state forces who prevented civil war. The problem is rooted in unionist neglect of history. I attended two schools that were culturally British, yet was being exposed to text books in the s that subtly pushed the apartheid NI lie .. Don’t fuel the New Ireland pushThe Republic has changed radically since , when Home Rule really was Rome Rule, but Brexit has also revealed an enduring anglophobia. Unionists should stop giving cover to an ‘old’ united Ireland plan, to shunt us out of a society of  million people into an small island unit that will align itself with Germany and France before recognising the huge historic British contribution to this island. Celebrate the NI centenaryThe downplaying of the centenary of our country, Northern Irleand, is a scandal. But as we emerge from lockdown we still have six months to celebrate, in a non tribal way, what London won’t.. Reject the NI ProtocolThere are strong pragmatic arguments for the protocol but they are not unionist ones. Yet Edwin Poots seems as pragmatic about the Irish Sea border as was Arlene Foster. Doug Beattie said on Good Morning Ulster this week that the NHS was more important than the protocol. Why keep unionist in the title of his partyso The UK has said in court that the Act of Union is repealed. That has to be the number one issue for anyone whose objective is staying in one of the greatest nations in history.. Unionists are not AllianceThe Alliance Party vote has risen to %+. But unionism on a bad day still gets %. Some people are talking up the Alliance surge to get unionists to move closer to a position of agnosticism on the Union. Don’t. . Get tough on securitySee on page  a bid for tougher on terror sentencing in GB. Yet NI is still soft about dissident bail and sentencing. Unionists should demand Stormont gets robust on those who kill.. Conscience is privateSame-sex relations, abortion, etc are conscience issues. If the UUP wants to encourage liberal positions and the DUP traditional ones, they should still allow a free vote.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: DUP in crisis - PSNI receive complaint that DUP members were allegedly threatened and intimidated by UDA   Judge has ‘heavy heart’ as he jails brothers with clear records for attack on police at internment bonfireNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedHome and GardenTechnologyFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsAfter dispatching Arlene Foster, Edwin Poots faces a mutinous DUPAfter overthrowing the old order and seeing off a late counter-insurgency, Edwin Poots was last night facing the prospect of leading a perpetually warring DUP.By Sam McBrideSaturday, th May , : am  "       "  ]]Cartoonist Brian John Spencer’s take on the battle at the top of the DUPThe Lagan Valley MLA’s election as DUP leader was ratied with more than % of the votes at the party executive on Thursday night.But that only came after a narrower vote to reject a secret ballot, something which supporters of Mr Poots’s leadership rival, Sir Jeffrey Donaldson had pushed for, believing that it might be possible to overturn the outcome of the vote by the party’s MPs and MLAs a fortnight ago to make Mr Poots leader-designate.Last night a senior DUP source who voted for Sir Jeffrey told the News Letter that iniduals across the party were considering resignation, with some likely to go to the UUP, amid dismay at Mr Poots’s leadership.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...The source said that North Antrim MP Ian Paisley Jr’s claim on Thursday night that his father had died of a broken heart after being toppled as DUP leader in  had exposed a key source of the party’s ision.They said: “Ian’s contribution was really signicant in laying bare the real reason for a lot of this. It’s about ing the DUP to its roots.”However, a source on Mr Poots’s side of the party said that it had been a power struggle and that those who until now had been the party establishment “just can’t come to terms with the fact that they’ve lost power”.Sir Jeffrey, outgoing leader Arlene Foster, Economy Minister Diane Dodds, East Belfast MP Gavin Robinson, East Londonderry MP Gregory Campbell and others then walked out during an interval in the meeting, pointedly not staying to listen to the new leader’s acceptance speech.Former Fermanagh and South Tyrone DUP constituency association chairman Paul Bell resigned on the steps of the Crowne Plaza hotel where the meeting was happening, telling reporters that senior party figures acted to “assassinate our leader”.However, he inadvertently confirmed something which earlier in the week Mrs Foster has questioned — the existence of the letter of no confidence which persuaded her to walk away.Mrs Foster had said that she had not seen the letter and suggested it might not exist, but Mr Bell said: “I think that those  members have a lot to think about — that signed that letter [sic]”.Veteran BBC political corespondent Gareth Gordon, who spent Thursday night at the hotel reporting on the drama, said yesterday: “The poison that’s pouring out is just incredible. It’s almost asit’s been kept bottled up for years ... nobody is trying to hide it.”Yesterday did not see a slew of public resignations from the party, but there was a mutinous atmosphere among many of those who opposed Mr Poots for the leadership.Some senior figures on Sir Jeffrey Donaldson’s side of the party are considering radical options.Last night one such inidual did not dismiss the idea of a string of unionist independents banding together in an alliance — although they accepted that there is not space for a fourth major unionist party.When askedthe imperative to unite for next year’s crucial assembly election will bring the party together behind the new leader or whether the isions are too deep to be bridged, he said: “I think it’s the latter more than the former. “We will lose people.”He added that it was “a huge mistake on Edwin’s part” to deny the party executive a secret vote on whether to raty him as leader.As the party spin about being a “family” was exposed, last night the PSNI confirmed they were investigatinga complaint that members of the party had been threatened during the leadership contestJournalist Rodney Edwards reported that Sir Jeffrey told Thursday night’s meeting that the UDA had “threatened” some of his team during the contest.The DUP said in a statement: “There was no intimidation or bullying. Any suggestions are baseless and without foundation. “Executive members freely expressed their opinions without fear or favour.”Mr Poots yesterday condemned the allegation and said that the police should deal with it.Yesterday Mrs Foster confirmed that she plans to leave the DUP and local politics entirely when she resigns as first minister. And the DUP leader threatened to quit that post next weekMr Poots decides to carry a reshuffle of the party’s ministerial team.When askedshe had any regrets, she said: “All of us are going to look back and wish we had done some things dferently. But it’s important to learn from that – everyone makes mistakes, but we should use the lessons from this to move forward.”Yesterday former DUP councillor Guy Spence, who quit the party last year in circumstance which have not been publicly explained, said on Twitter: “When I felt the wrath of the twisted, bitter, hateful culture of the DUP over a year ago I asked the leadership for an investigation.“They washed their hands and looked the other way without responding, instead focusing on spin and deflection.“A year on, they now know what it feels like as the stench brewing on their watch has erupted all over themselves.”Reflecting on the public stre, former DUP MLA David McIlveen said that “the ramications for the unionist family are potentially catastrophic”.He told the Nolan Show that  was “a year in which unionism should have been rejuvenating itself” as it marked the centenary but instead the DUP was tearing itself apart.The former North Antrim MLA said that “the only losers in this are unionism” and that for those losing positions at the top of the DUP “le will go on for them”, but unionism will suffer.Mr McIlveen, the son of Free Presbyterian minister the Rev David McIlveen, said that “there is a culture of fear within the party” and that “no lessons have been learned” by the party since the RHI scandal.New Ulster Unionist leader Doug Beattie, whose ratication as leader on Thursday was as smooth as the DUP’s was messy, said that his party was talking to at least five DUP councillors but they must “share our vision” before joining.:Sam McBride: A title: covid  indian variant hotspots uk revealed
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. are concerns the Indian iant could see cases jump back up.Data from Public Health Englandshows a rise in cases from  to , this week in the UK, with the agency saying cases were ldquorising in the community and it was assessing the impact and severity of the iant.One response being considered is bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the situation was being monitored carefully and the Government ldquowill not hesitate to take further actionnecessary.However, a small number of areas are seeing a rise in cases as the India iant spreads across the UK.The Prime Minister has said there is "increasing concern" about the iant and warned the emergence of further new iants "pose a potentially lethal danger".Where is the India iant dominant Surge testing has been under way in parts of Bolton since  May, after Public Health Englandconfirmed the town is one of the main locations of the India iant, which was reclassied as a lsquoiant of concernrsquo last week.Cases of the iant in England increased from  to  as of  May, according to PHE figures, with almost half of these related to travel or contact with a traveller.The majority of cases of the India Covid strain are concentrated in the north-west of England, predominantly in Bolton, and in London.The iant is also thought to be the reason behind half of coronavirus infections in Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen and South Northamptonshire, although these outbreaks are still small.Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has submitted a request to the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation that all over-s in Bolton, along with the rest of the Greater Manchester area, are able to receive a Covid- vaccination ldquoto mitigate the risks of spread in those communities where we are seeing more transmission.     There are also around  to  cases of the India iant in parts of Scotland, including Glasgow, with these cases again connected to travel.The India Covid iant, officially known as B.., was first detected in India in October.It has been designated a ldquoiant of concern by PHE as it is thought to be at least as transmissible as the iant detected in Kent last year, known as B, which is now dominant in the UK.PHE said there is currently no evidence to suggest that the new Indian iant is more serious than previous mutations, nor is there evidence which indicates that this version of the Indian iant is resistant to current vaccines.Health experts said they ldquohavenrsquot seen any hint of a current Covid iant that can fully evade the effectiveness of vaccines.On Wednesday , the European Medicines Agency said it was ldquopretty confident that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant, a view that has been echoed by some British scientists.However, Professor James Naismith from the University of Oxford said not enough is known to say for sure whether the iant could frustrate the UKrsquos vaccination programme.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoThe vaccines donrsquot  per cent prevent infection for people.ldquoWhat they do is, they almost  per cent prevent hospitalisation and serious illness.ldquoWe donrsquot know enough to know yet whether the Indian strain will behave dferently than that.ldquoSo even the regular virus can infect people who have been vaccinated and sometimes you do get reinfection.Could the iant delay lockdown ending The growing number of India Covid iant cases in the UK has sparked concerns that the lting of lockdown restrictions, which is set for  June in England, could now be delayed.Ministers have also not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.Foreign Office minister James Cleverly said that the government will make decisions based on the data, and measures will be eased ldquoat a pace and in a way which is safe.Symptoms to look forThe main symptoms of coronavirus to look for include:a high temperature ndash this means you feel hot to touch on your chest or back a new, continuous cough ndash this means coughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste ndash this means youve noticed you cannot smell or taste anything, or things smell or taste dferent to normalMost people with symptoms have at least one of these symptoms, although some do not experience any. title: penarth ramblers explore history nature walk
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt was girl power when ten female walkers joined Joy and sheepdog Bracken from Penarth and District Ramblers at Penarth clftop for an . mile walk, with no stiles only gates and which would see them experiencing the weather of all four seasons in one day. They set off on a socially distanced walk in lovely spring sunshine across the old pitch and putt course before joining part of the old railway line, now a walk and cycle way, and heading through a built up area Lavernock Road led them into Cosmeston Country Park.Past the eastern lake with its floating jetty where canoes can be safely launched and making their way through the eastern paddock with its carpet of pretty cowslips, open meadows led them towards Old Cogan Hall Farm, where they deviated into the churchyard of St Peterrsquos for morning break in glorious warm sunshine reminiscent of summer. Admiring the herring bone masonry which dates to Celtic and Saxon times and the ancient yew trees that could even pre-date this lovely old church, which allegedly is the oldest building in Penarth and hearing some of its long and interesting history, it fell into disrepair in the th century. By the th century the ruinous building was a cattle shelter until the latter part of the rsquos when the rd Marquis of Bute was persuaded to pay for its renovation.Mile Road built by the Bute family led them to the western paddock and through the sun-dappled Cogan Wood to re-enter fields where a footbridge led them across the Sully Brook for the short climb up to Home Farm, with its glorious views towards the eastern end of Barry and the surrounding farmland. Exiting through a gate, some road walking in a southerly direction brought them into Sully village and pounding pavements to reach the Jubilee Hall and the cricket field, the full beauty of Sully Bay with its views across the Bristol Channel towards the Somerset coastline and Hayes Point to the west confronted them.     With the wind beginning to pick up they tramped by track and field to the public slipway at Sully beach and stopped for lunch utilising rocks for seating whilst gazing eastwards towards Sully Island and Flat and Steep Holm beyond, as clouds thickened overhead and the temperature dropped making it feel more like autumn.Time to move on along part of the long distance Wales Coast Path, through the playing fields to exit onto Beach Road, following it to the car park of the Captainrsquos We where there were only a few people sitting at outdoor tables for food and drink, not really enjoyable in the cool breeze.The fairly quiet St Maryrsquos Well Bay Road brought them up past The Bay Caravan Park and into fields with growing crops where, without any warning a sudden short sharp shower of rain engulfed the group forcing coats to be swtly donned.Crossing a wooden footbridge into the delightful Lavernock Nature Reserve the grassy path led them into the remains of the WW gun emplacements. Initially in the late rsquos the original Lavernock Gun Battery was built to protect the Bristol and Cardf shipyards and the Bristol Channel, but unfortunately most of the original buildings now lie underneath the caravan park.Being bombarded by a short hail storm whilst moving on through the nature reserve, lovingly cared for by volunteers and passing the man-made pond with its surrounding carpet of bluish violet bugle, a plant which attracts moths, butterflies and bees, before exiting onto Fort Road their route led them past the Marconi Holiday Village and the Church of St Lawrence before heading along the clftop. With thick black clouds heading up the English side of the Bristol Channel, the race was on to get back before the rain hit. As the weather turned wintry and the wind increased, a huge shower of hailstones and heavy rain struck them on the open Penarth clftop soaking them as they made their way back to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits before, during and after lockdown on Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: sotm st richard gwyn catholic high school barry
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySt Richard GwynCatholic High School, on Argae Lane in Barry, has  pupils currently on roll, with this number increasing to  - the schoolrsquos biggest Year Seven cohort yet.Mr David Blackwell has been head teacher at the school since February , following his role as deputy head for more than four years.Headteacher Mr David BlackwellHe is backed by deputy head Matthew Dunn assistant headteachers Laura Burnettand Amy Leftleyand senior core leader Sharon Macleod.The schoolrsquos last Estyn report was in  ndash the school was rated lsquoadequatersquo overall but with good prospects of improvement.Explaining some of the improvements made since, Mr Blackwell said: ldquoWe have fully embedded the Jesuit Pupil Profile into the le of staff and students."The Jesuit Pupil Profile gives a focus to the citizens that we wish to nurture at SRG. It reminds staff and students that virtues towards the needs of others is paramount to the essence of our humanity."He continued: We have always prioritised wellbeing of our students but over the last two years we have developed a lsquowellbeing progress centre. Support staff have been trained extensively to ensure that all students are ready to learn.ldquoThe wellbeing team are always on hand to assist with the students wellbeing by offering sessions for ELSA, Thrive and Mental Health Wellbeing. We even have two wellbeing dogs that support some of our more vulnerable learners.ldquoWe work very closely with a iety of external agencies to support our students needs to ensure students are engaged and feel safe and secure and able to fulfil their full potential.The school caters to pupils with additional learning needs and to staff wellbeing. Staff at the school have training, progression opportunities, open door policy of support, and clear lines of communication.     ldquoTeaching and learning continues to be our core focus, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoThe  Inspection report praised students at SRG for lsquotheir positive attitude to learningrsquo. We have built upon this and we now offer a Scholarrsquos Programme to prepare students for their education pathway.ldquoWe want to offer students a chance to broaden their educational experience with us. We have broadened our option subjects at KS - we are now able to offer Construction, Health and Social Care and Textiles and Fashion.ldquoWe are committed to the promotion of SRG as a learning organisation. To this end we have entered into an ITE Partnership with Cardf politan University and an alliance with St.Illtydrsquos Catholic Comprehensive in Cardf. It is mutually beneficial since we help develop new teachers into the profession and we are able to utilise educational research to improve standards across both key stages.The Catholic school strives to ensures pupils succeed, while also being good people.ldquoWe aim for our pupils to live by the ethos of our pupil profile which is about virtues to empower them to be a success in le, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe are the faith secondary school of the Vale and so provide an excellent secondary education that runs equally alongside our holistic development of our pupils as iniduals and good all round people.The Catholic ethos is embedded into daily le at the school, with morning prayer, virtues-based assemblies, and daily reflection.ldquoAll staff engage in role modelling behaviour that reflects the Catholic virtues of honesty, integrity and forgiveness, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoDuring normal school times Mass is a frequent part of our school le ndash not all pupils come to us with a faith background, but they all appreciate the values that we try to weave into our everyday lives.Along with the schoolrsquos ethical focus St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School has an abundance of extra-curricular activities on offer, including school trips.Sporty youngsters can take part in football, rugby, netball, hockey, tennis, badminton, athletics, cheerleading and street dance. Therersquos also Clwb Cymraeg and an array of creative activities on offer ndash including art club, textiles club, choir, SRG band.Bi-annually the music, drama, and art departments join forces to produce and perform an arts production.St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School strives to form lsquopositive relationshipsrsquo with families and the local community and has a Facebook group regularly updated with video messages from Mr Blackwell and key messages for families.Each year group has a Progress Leader who is a point of contact for families as well as our Wellbeing and Progress Centre who liaises with families on a regular basis. Plus, St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School is in the process of obtaining the Investors in Families , which ndash in a nutshell ndash lsquois a quality mark that recognises the work that schools and other settings undertake with families to improve outcomes for children and young people.rsquoThe school is also lsquoproudrsquo to have worked with numerous charities ndash including fundraising for local food banks and helping Keep Wales Tidy with beach cleans.The school has also adapted a lsquogreatrsquo deal during the coronavirus pandemic ndash with the immediate priority being health and safety such as year group lsquobubblesrsquo, separate lunches, allocated outdoor spaces, regular sanitizing and face coverings.ldquoThe biggest impact, in terms of day to day operation, meant teachers moved more between lessons than students, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoCrucial to adapting to the pandemic was to adoption of online learning. There have been periods of lockdown with no pupils in school as well as fortnightly periods that have required year groups to isolate.He praised the training and use of online s as lsquotransformativersquo. and added that - while itrsquos lsquofantasticrsquo to resume in-person learning these changes and developments will continue to improve how the school operates.The school is lsquovery fortunatersquo to have been supported by the local authority to make the best of the buildings they have, but the school is awaiting progress on a new build under the st Century schools programme, financed by Welsh Government.ldquoWe firmly believe that what goes on inside school is more important than the way the building looks externally, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe have amazing staff who work exceptionally hard to make the best of the facilities we have, all pupils who come to us get a great educational experience.ldquoHowever, we are still awaiting progress on a new build. We will continue to work hard to improve our facilities with the support of our Governors and the local authority, but at the same time we will continue to lobby to get the new build progressed as soon as possible so that our pupils not only get a fantastic experience, but they also get it in state-of-the-art facilities they deserve. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will also move temporarily to the iconic art deco building on the Esplanade, which was recently taken over by Vale of Glamorgan council.More than a thousand people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the pavilion, with many supporting something similar to Chapter.Details of the responses to the consultation were revealed in a report to the councilrsquos cabinet, which meets on Wednesday, May , as well as the costs of recent repair work.The pavilion building first opened in . It was used for dances during the second world war, and a nightclub in the s and s. The building fell into disrepair about a decade ago, but a charity called Penarth Arts and Craft Limited spent lottery funding on renovation.Then the pavilion reopened in  as an arts and culture venue with a cinema, exhibition space, meeting rooms and a cafe. However, the charity later struggled with directors leaving and challenging trading conditions, particularly during the coronavirus pandemic.MORE NEWS:Towards the end of last year, the charity entered discussions with the Vale council and the National Lottery about what could be done. The council then took over control of the building last February, and asked the public for suggestions about how the pavilion should be used.A new cafe has opened in the pavilion, run by the councilrsquos armrsquosBig Fresh Catering Company. All profits from this company are put into providing healthy meals for schools.Essential repairs and maintenance have also been carried out on the building, including replacing the air conditioning repairing the lighting, fire doors, and gas boilers and testing the lt, water hygiene, and fire alarms. Initial works have cost about pound,.     The kitchen has also seen repairs and cleaning outside walls have been cleaned and the decking jet washed tables have been sanded and resealed and a broken window was replaced. Public wi has been improved and the cinema projector has been maintained.The childrenrsquos section of Penarth Library will temporarily be relocated to the pavilion. The section is currently not well ventilated enough to be Covid-secure, but it should be in the pavilion. Regular activities like Story Time will be held at the pavilion.The building could also soon host live music and a bar, as the council is applying for licences to play music and serve alcohol there.More than , people responded to a public consultation on what should happen next with the building from March  until April . Most would like to see included in the plans a cinema, cafe, bar or street food space also with live music, theatre and comedy shows.Some respondents suggested the pavilion could run similar to Chapter Arts in Cardf. Council bosses are now drawing up a business plan which should include firmer details on what will happen next to the building. title: bethan roper inquest jury hears friends
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. Railwaytravelling at around mph.Miss Roper, of Penarth, was ing home to South Wales from a day out with friends Christmas shopping in Bath.Avon Coronerrsquos Court heard Miss Roper and her three friends, Elizabeth Winstone Evans, Chanelle Hagland and Madeleine Owens, had boarded the train at Bath Spa station on the evening of December , .The GWR London Paddington to Exeter service was using carriages fitted with droplight windows to enable passengers to use the handle on the outside when they needed to leave the train at the .Investigators told the inquest that the warning label above the window, a yellow sticker with the words: lsquoCaution do not lean out of window when train is movingrsquo, was not a sufficient deterrent.Miss Roper was fatally injured just a few minutes after the train left Bath when her head was struck by an ash tree branch growing on land adjacent to the line.PC Kate Aldred, of British Transport Police, spoke with Miss Hagland when the train arrived at Bristol Temple Meads station shortly after the incident and made written notes of the conversation.ldquoThe train had been travelling five or six minutes when Miss Evans opened the pulldown window of the door, Pc Aldred said.ldquoMiss Evans leant her head out of the window very slightly for about  seconds and then said something like, lsquoGirls try thisrsquo.ldquoMiss Evans put her head back title: blockbuster movies ready for omniplex reopening
story: Traffic Attendants back on streets next week   Toddler, who died in tragic incident, is named locallyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleBlockbuster movies ready for Omniplex reopeningMovie buffs will be delighted that the local Omniplex chain is all set to reopen to the public next Monday - pending the easing of Lockdown restrictions.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  Ready to roll out the reels, the Omniplex Cinemas are awaiting official confirmation from the NI Executive - which is due on Thursday .The cinema chain plans to begin its phased reopening of five sites, with Omniplex Craigavon Lisburn, Dundonald, Newry and Bangor welcoming customers back to a covid safe way from this date. Eight more Omniplex locations across the country are ready to resume screening from Friday th May marking the first time this year for avid movie goers to enjoy the big screen experience. ]]Craigavon Omniplex.The cinema chain – the largest in NI, closed all of its venues on December , , when all areas of the UK and Ireland were under pandemic restrictions. Paul John Anderson, Director of Omniplex Cinemas said: “We are thrilled to finally be welcoming back cinema goers for the first time this year. We strongly believe in the power of escapism that a couple of hours spent at the cinema provides and we are looking forward to opening our doors for the ultimate big screen experience. We have worked hard over the last year to ensure our customers can enjoy the magic of cinema once again. We continue to follow public health advice and the safety of our team and customers remains of utmost importance.” Safety measures will include limited capacity m distance between parties for social distancing requirements face coverings to be worn by staff and audiences when moving within cinema buildings and staggered showtimes to name a few. Omniplex Cinemas will also be operating enhanced online booking to make the visit as contactless as possible with increased cleaning regimes and hand sanitising stations in every foyer. Visitors will be expected to wear face masks but will be allowed to remove them when seated in auditoriums for eating or drinking. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives. We know that our audiences are eager to get back to the big screen and we cannot wait to see people experiencing the cinema once again.” Several film studios had paused the release of their ‘tentpole’ blockbusters in , opting for release dates in the latter half of . From th May, film fans can enjoy films including Peter Rabbit , voiced by stars including James Corden and Margot Robbie and much-anticipated horror film The Conjuring . A raft of blockbuster films is set to be released in this summer with Marvel releasing the much-delayed Black Widow on th July. DC Comics will play to a similar field of movie goers with the release of The Suicide Squad on th August. The ninth instalment of Fast and Furious will come to cinema screens across NI on th July this year. The th James Bond will also grace the movie screens with No Time to Die featuring Daniel Craig as  expected to come out on th September in the UK and Ireland. Tickets are on sale now in advance of these reopening dates at www.omniplex.ie. The remaining sites in Derry, Belfast, Antrim, Carrickfergus, Omagh, Downpatrick, Banbridge and Dungannon will open again from Friday th May. Omniplex is the largest cinema chain in Ireland, with over  screens in  locations.
